So if you start a successful startup, odds are you'll start one of those.Another way to say that is, if you try to start the kind of startup that has to be a big consumer brand, the odds against succeeding are steeper.
paragraphs.translated: 每个人都知道这些，因为它们是大型消费品牌。但每个这样的初创企业背后，还有二十个在细分市场运营或默默无闻地在基础设施领域发展的企业。所以，如果你创办了一个成功的初创企业，很可能你创办的就是其中之一。换句话说，如果你试图创办那种必须成为大型消费品牌的初创企业，成功的机会就会更加渺茫。

paragraphs.original: The best odds are in niche markets. Since startups make money by offering people something better than they had before, the best opportunities are where things suck most. And it would be hard to find a place where things suck more than in corporate IT departments.
paragraphs.translated: 最佳机会在于细分市场。由于初创公司通过提供比之前更好的产品或服务来赚钱，因此最好的机会出现在那些现状最糟糕的领域。而很难找到比企业IT部门现状更糟糕的地方了。

paragraphs.original: You would not believe the amount of money companies spend on software, and the crap they get in return. This imbalance equals opportunity.If you want ideas for startups, one of the most valuable things you could do is find a middle-sized non-technology company and spend a couple weeks just watching what they do with computers.
paragraphs.translated: 你难以想象公司花在软件上的钱有多少，以及他们得到的垃圾产品。这种不平衡就意味着机会。如果你想创业，最 valuable 的事情之一就是找一家中等规模的非科技公司，花几周时间观察他们如何使用计算机。

paragraphs.original: Most good hackers have no more idea of the horrors perpetrated in these places than rich Americans do of what goes on in Brazilian slums.Start by writing software for smaller companies, because it's easier to sell to them.
paragraphs.translated: 大多数优秀的黑客对这些地方发生的恐怖行为一无所知，就像富裕的美国人不了解巴西贫民窟的情况一样。先从为小公司编写软件开始，因为向他们销售更容易。

paragraphs.original: It's worth so much to sell stuff to big companies that the people selling them the crap they currently use spend a lot of time and money to do it. And while you can outhack Oracle with one frontal lobe tied behind your back, you can't outsell an Oracle salesman.
paragraphs.translated: 向大公司出售东西非常有利可图，以至于那些向他们推销当前使用的产品的人会花费大量的时间和金钱来做这件事。虽然你可以用一只手绑在背后的情况下仍能胜过甲骨文的技术，但你无法在销售上击败甲骨文的销售人员。

paragraphs.original: So if you want to win through better technology, aim at smaller customers. [4]They're the more strategically valuable part of the market anyway. In technology, the low end always eats the high end. It's easier to make an inexpensive product more powerful than to make a powerful product cheaper.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，如果你想通过更好的技术赢得市场，就瞄准较小的客户。[4]他们本就是市场上更具战略价值的部分。在技术领域，低端总是吞噬高端。让一个价格低廉的产品变得更强大，比让一个强大的产品变得更便宜要容易。

paragraphs.original: So the products that start as cheap, simple options tend to gradually grow more powerful till, like water rising in a room, they squash the "high-end" products against the ceiling. Sun did this to mainframes, and Intel is doing it to Sun.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，那些最初作为廉价、简单的选项出现的产品，往往会逐渐变得越来越强大，就像房间里的水位上升一样，将“高端”产品挤压到天花板上。Sun 公司就是这样对大型机做的，而 Intel 也正在对 Sun 做同样的事情。

paragraphs.original: Microsoft Word did it to desktop publishing software like Interleaf and Framemaker. Mass-market digital cameras are doing it to the expensive models made for professionals. Avid did it to the manufacturers of specialized video editing systems, and now Apple is doing it to Avid.
paragraphs.translated: 微软的Word对Interleaf和Framemaker等桌面出版软件做了这件事。大众市场的数字相机正在对专业级昂贵的相机模型做同样的事情。Avid对专业视频编辑系统的制造商做了这件事，现在苹果又对Avid做了同样的事情。

paragraphs.original: Henry Ford did it to the car makers that preceded him. If you build the simple, inexpensive option, you'll not only find it easier to sell at first, but you'll also be in the best position to conquer the rest of the market.It's very dangerous to let anyone fly under you.
paragraphs.translated: 亨利·福特对他的前辈汽车制造商们就是这样做的。如果你制造的是简单且价格低廉的选项，你不仅在一开始会发现销售更容易，而且还能处于最佳位置去征服剩余的市场。让任何人从你下面超越是非常危险的。

paragraphs.original: If you have the cheapest, easiest product, you'll own the low end. And if you don't, you're in the crosshairs of whoever does.Raising MoneyTo make all this happen, you're going to need money. Some startups have been self-funding-- Microsoft for example-- but most aren't.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你有最便宜、最容易使用的产品，你就能占领低端市场。而如果你没有，拥有这样产品的人就会瞄准你。为了实现这一切，你需要资金。有些初创公司是自我融资的——比如微软——但大多数都不是。

paragraphs.original: I think it's wise to take money from investors. To be self-funding, you have to start as a consulting company, and it's hard to switch from that to a product company.Financially, a startup is like a pass/fail course.
paragraphs.translated: 我认为从投资者那里募集资金是明智的。如果自我融资，你不得不先从咨询公司做起，而从咨询公司转型为产品公司是非常困难的。从财务角度来看，创业公司就像一门及格/不及格的课程。

paragraphs.original: The way to get rich from a startup is to maximize the company's chances of succeeding, not to maximize the amount of stock you retain. So if you can trade stock for something that improves your odds, it's probably a smart move.To most hackers, getting investors seems like a terrifying and mysterious process.
paragraphs.translated: 从创业公司获利的方法是最大化公司成功的机会，而不是最大化你所持有的股份。因此，如果你能用股份换取能提高成功几率的东西，那很可能是一个明智的决定。对大多数程序员来说，吸引投资者似乎是一个既恐怖又神秘的过程。

paragraphs.original: Actually it's merely tedious. I'll try to give an outline of how it works.The first thing you'll need is a few tens of thousands of dollars to pay your expenses while you develop a prototype. This is called seed capital.
paragraphs.translated: 实际上这仅仅是繁琐的工作。我会尽量概述它是如何运作的。首先，你需要几万美元来支付你在开发原型期间的费用。这被称为种子资金。

paragraphs.original: Because so little money is involved, raising seed capital is comparatively easy-- at least in the sense of getting a quick yes or no.Usually you get seed money from individual rich people called "angels." Often they're people who themselves got rich from technology.
paragraphs.translated: 由于涉及的资金很少，筹集种子资金相对来说较为容易——至少在获得快速肯定或否定答复方面是这样。通常，种子资金来自被称为“天使投资人”的富裕个人。他们往往自己就是从科技行业发家致富的。

paragraphs.original: At the seed stage, investors don't expect you to have an elaborate business plan. Most know that they're supposed to decide quickly. It's not unusual to get a check within a week based on a half-page agreement.We started Viaweb with $10,000 of seed money from our friend Julian.
paragraphs.translated: 在种子阶段，投资者并不期望你有一个详尽的商业计划。大多数人都知道他们应该迅速做出决定。在基于半页协议的情况下，一周内拿到支票并不罕见。我们从朋友朱利安那里获得了10,000美元的种子资金，开始了Viaweb。

paragraphs.original: But he gave us a lot more than money. He's a former CEO and also a corporate lawyer, so he gave us a lot of valuable advice about business, and also did all the legal work of getting us set up as a company.
paragraphs.translated: 但他给我们的远不止金钱。他曾经是CEO，也是一名公司律师，因此他给了我们很多宝贵的商业建议，还帮我们完成了公司成立的所有法律工作。

paragraphs.original: Plus he introduced us to one of the two angel investors who supplied our next round of funding.Some angels, especially those with technology backgrounds, may be satisfied with a demo and a verbal description of what you plan to do.
paragraphs.translated: 此外，他还向我们引荐了一位天使投资人，后者为我们提供了下一轮融资。一些天使投资人，尤其是那些具有技术背景的，可能只要一个演示和对你计划要做的事情的口头描述就满足了。

paragraphs.original: But many will want a copy of your business plan, if only to remind themselves what they invested in.Our angels asked for one, and looking back, I'm amazed how much worry it caused me. "Business plan" has that word "business" in it, so I figured it had to be something I'd have to read a book about business plans to write.
paragraphs.translated: 但许多人会希望得到一份你的商业计划书，哪怕只是为了提醒他们自己投资的是什么。我们的天使投资人就要求提供一份，回想起来，我惊讶于它曾给我带来多少烦恼。“商业计划”这个词里有“商业”这个词，所以我以为我必须读一本关于商业计划的书才能写出来。

paragraphs.original: Well, it doesn't. At this stage, all most investors expect is a brief description of what you plan to do and how you're going to make money from it, and the resumes of the founders. If you just sit down and write out what you've been saying to one another, that should be fine.
paragraphs.translated: 好吧，其实不用那么复杂。在这个阶段，大多数投资者只是希望看到一个简短的描述，说明你打算做什么，以及你将如何从中盈利，还有创始人的简历。如果你坐下来把你之前和合伙人讨论的内容写出来，应该就足够了。

paragraphs.original: It shouldn't take more than a couple hours, and you'll probably find that writing it all down gives you more ideas about what to do.For the angel to have someone to make the check out to, you're going to have to have some kind of company.
paragraphs.translated: 这不应该花费超过几个小时，而且你可能会发现，把一切都写下来会让你有更多的想法。为了让天使投资人有一个可以开具支票的对象，你必须得有一个某种形式的公司。

paragraphs.original: Merely incorporating yourselves isn't hard. The problem is, for the company to exist, you have to decide who the founders are, and how much stock they each have. If there are two founders with the same qualifications who are both equally committed to the business, that's easy.
paragraphs.translated: 仅仅注册公司并不难。问题在于，为了让公司存在，你们必须决定谁是创始人，以及他们各自拥有多少股份。如果有两位创始人，资质相同且对业务的投入程度也一样，那就很简单了。

paragraphs.original: But if you have a number of people who are expected to contribute in varying degrees, arranging the proportions of stock can be hard. And once you've done it, it tends to be set in stone.I have no tricks for dealing with this problem.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，如果你有一群人，他们被期望以不同程度贡献，那么安排股权比例可能会很困难。而且一旦确定下来，这些比例往往就固定不变了。对于这个问题，我没有什么解决的妙招。

paragraphs.original: All I can say is, try hard to do it right. I do have a rule of thumb for recognizing when you have, though. When everyone feels they're getting a slightly bad deal, that they're doing more than they should for the amount of stock they have, the stock is optimally apportioned.There is more to setting up a company than incorporating it, of course: insurance, business license, unemployment compensation, various things with the IRS.
paragraphs.translated: 我只能说，尽力把它做好。不过，我确实有一个经验法则来判断你是否做到了。当每个人都觉得自己得到了稍微不那么好的待遇，觉得自己为所持有的股份做出了超出应有的贡献时，股份的分配就是最优的。当然，成立一家公司不仅仅是注册那么简单：还有保险、营业执照、失业补偿、与美国国税局相关的各种事宜。

paragraphs.original: I'm not even sure what the list is, because we, ah, skipped all that. When we got real funding near the end of 1996, we hired a great CFO, who fixed everything retroactively. It turns out that no one comes and arrests you if you don't do everything you're supposed to when starting a company.
paragraphs.translated: 我甚至不确定那份清单是什么，因为我们，啊，跳过了所有那些步骤。当我们在1996年底获得真正融资时，聘请了一位很棒的首席财务官，他后来把一切都补办妥了。结果证明，如果你在创业初期没有按照规定做所有的事情，也不会有人来逮捕你。

paragraphs.original: And a good thing too, or a lot of startups would never get started. [5]It can be dangerous to delay turning yourself into a company, because one or more of the founders might decide to split off and start another company doing the same thing.
paragraphs.translated: 这倒是件好事，否则很多初创公司就无法启动了。[5]延迟将自己转变为公司可能会很危险，因为一位或多位创始人可能会决定分道扬镳，另起炉灶做同样的事情。

paragraphs.original: This does happen. So when you set up the company, as well as as apportioning the stock, you should get all the founders to sign something agreeing that everyone's ideas belong to this company, and that this company is going to be everyone's only job.[If this were a movie, ominous music would begin here.]While you're at it, you should ask what else they've signed.
paragraphs.translated: 这确实会发生。因此，在成立公司时，除了分配股份外，还应让所有创始人签署协议，同意所有人的想法都属于这家公司，并且这家公司将成为每个人唯一的全职工作。【如果这是一部电影，此时背景音乐将变得阴郁起来。】同时，你还应该询问他们还签署了哪些其他文件。

paragraphs.original: One of the worst things that can happen to a startup is to run into intellectual property problems. We did, and it came closer to killing us than any competitor ever did.As we were in the middle of getting bought, we discovered that one of our people had, early on, been bound by an agreement that said all his ideas belonged to the giant company that was paying for him to go to grad school.
paragraphs.translated: 对初创公司来说，最糟糕的事情之一就是遇到知识产权问题。我们的确遇到了，而且它比任何竞争对手都更接近于将我们置于死地。在我们正被收购的过程中，我们发现，我们的一名员工在早期曾签署过一项协议，该协议规定他的所有想法都属于那家资助他读研究生的大型公司。

paragraphs.original: In theory, that could have meant someone else owned big chunks of our software. So the acquisition came to a screeching halt while we tried to sort this out. The problem was, since we'd been about to be acquired, we'd allowed ourselves to run low on cash.
paragraphs.translated: 理论上，这可能意味着其他人拥有我们软件的大块部分。因此，收购戛然而止，我们试图解决这个问题。问题是，由于我们即将被收购，我们允许自己的现金流变得紧张。

paragraphs.original: Now we needed to raise more to keep going. But it's hard to raise money with an IP cloud over your head, because investors can't judge how serious it is.Our existing investors, knowing that we needed money and had nowhere else to get it, at this point attempted certain gambits which I will not describe in detail, except to remind readers that the word "angel" is a metaphor.
paragraphs.translated: 现在我们需要筹集更多资金才能继续下去。但是，头顶上笼罩着知识产权的阴云，融资变得十分困难，因为投资者无法判断问题的严重性。我们的现有投资者知道我们需要资金，而且没有其他途径可以获取资金，在这种情况下，他们采取了一些我不便详细描述的手段，只是提醒读者，“天使”一词只是一个比喻。

paragraphs.original: The founders thereupon proposed to walk away from the company, after giving the investors a brief tutorial on how to administer the servers themselves. And while this was happening, the acquirers used the delay as an excuse to welch on the deal.Miraculously it all turned out ok.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人们随后提议离开公司，在此之前给投资者们简要讲解了如何自行管理服务器。而在此期间，收购方利用这一拖延作为借口，试图反悔交易。奇迹般地，这一切最终还是顺利解决了。

paragraphs.original: The investors backed down; we did another round of funding at a reasonable valuation; the giant company finally gave us a piece of paper saying they didn't own our software; and six months later we were bought by Yahoo for much more than the earlier acquirer had agreed to pay.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者退缩了；我们以一个合理的估值进行了另一轮融资；那家大公司最终给我们开了一张纸，说明他们并不拥有我们的软件；六个月后，我们被雅虎收购，价格远高于之前收购方同意支付的金额。

paragraphs.original: So we were happy in the end, though the experience probably took several years off my life.Don't do what we did. Before you consummate a startup, ask everyone about their previous IP history.Once you've got a company set up, it may seem presumptuous to go knocking on the doors of rich people and asking them to invest tens of thousands of dollars in something that is really just a bunch of guys with some ideas.
paragraphs.translated: 所以最终我们是高兴的，尽管这次经历可能让我少活了几年。不要像我们这样做。在你建立一家初创公司之前，询问每个人他们之前的知识产权历史。一旦公司成立，去找富人敲门，请求他们为一些只是拥有几个点子的人投资数万美元，这可能会显得自不量力。

paragraphs.original: But when you look at it from the rich people's point of view, the picture is more encouraging. Most rich people are looking for good investments. If you really think you have a chance of succeeding, you're doing them a favor by letting them invest.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，从富人的角度来看，情况则更加乐观。大多数富人在寻找好的投资机会。如果你真的认为自己有成功的机会，那么让他们投资实际上是在帮他们的忙。

paragraphs.original: Mixed with any annoyance they might feel about being approached will be the thought: are these guys the next Google?Usually angels are financially equivalent to founders. They get the same kind of stock and get diluted the same amount in future rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 混杂着被接近时可能产生的不悦，他们心中会想：这些家伙会不会是下一个谷歌？通常天使投资者在财务上与创始人是等价的。他们获得同样类型的股票，并在未来几轮融资中以相同的程度被稀释。

paragraphs.original: How much stock should they get? That depends on how ambitious you feel. When you offer x percent of your company for y dollars, you're implicitly claiming a certain value for the whole company. Venture investments are usually described in terms of that number.
paragraphs.translated: 他们应该得到多少股份？这取决于你的野心有多大。当你以y美元的价格提供公司x%的股份时，实际上是在暗示整个公司的价值。风险投资通常以这个数字来描述。

paragraphs.original: If you give an investor new shares equal to 5% of those already outstanding in return for $100,000, then you've done the deal at a pre-money valuation of $2 million.How do you decide what the value of the company should be?
paragraphs.translated: 如果你以10万美元的价格向投资者提供相当于已发行股份5%的新股，那么这笔交易的投前估值为200万美元。你是如何决定公司的价值的？

paragraphs.original: There is no rational way. At this stage the company is just a bet. I didn't realize that when we were raising money. Julian thought we ought to value the company at several million dollars. I thought it was preposterous to claim that a couple thousand lines of code, which was all we had at the time, were worth several million dollars.
paragraphs.translated: 没有理性的方法。在这个阶段，公司只是一个赌注。在我们融资时，我没有意识到这一点。朱利安认为我们应该将公司的估值定为数百万美元。我觉得声称几千行代码，当时我们全部的成果，值数百万美元，是荒谬的。

paragraphs.original: Eventually we settled on one million, because Julian said no one would invest in a company with a valuation any lower. [6]What I didn't grasp at the time was that the valuation wasn't just the value of the code we'd written so far.
paragraphs.translated: 最终我们定为一百万美元，因为朱利安说没人会投资于估值更低的公司。[6]当时我没有意识到，估值并不仅仅是我们迄今为止所编写代码的价值。

paragraphs.original: It was also the value of our ideas, which turned out to be right, and of all the future work we'd do, which turned out to be a lot.The next round of funding is the one in which you might deal with actual venture capital firms.
paragraphs.translated: 这同样证明了我们想法的价值，事实证明这些想法是正确的，以及我们未来将要做的所有工作，结果证明这些工作量很大。下一轮融资可能就是你与真正的风险投资公司打交道的时候了。

paragraphs.original: But don't wait till you've burned through your last round of funding to start approaching them. VCs are slow to make up their minds. They can take months. You don't want to be running out of money while you're trying to negotiate with them.Getting money from an actual VC firm is a bigger deal than getting money from angels.
paragraphs.translated: 但不要等到你最后一轮融资的资金都花光了才开始接触他们。风险投资公司做决定很慢，可能需要好几个月。你不希望在和他们谈判的时候资金耗尽。从真正的风险投资公司获得资金比从天使投资人那里获得资金要重要得多。

paragraphs.original: The amounts of money involved are larger, millions usually. So the deals take longer, dilute you more, and impose more onerous conditions.Sometimes the VCs want to install a new CEO of their own choosing.
paragraphs.translated: 涉及的资金数额通常以数百万计。因此，交易耗时更长，稀释比例更大，并且会附加更苛刻的条件。有时，风险投资公司希望任命他们自己选定的新首席执行官。

paragraphs.original: Usually the claim is that you need someone mature and experienced, with a business background. Maybe in some cases this is true. And yet Bill Gates was young and inexperienced and had no business background, and he seems to have done ok.
paragraphs.translated: 通常的说法是，你需要一个成熟且有经验的人，具有商业背景。也许在某些情况下这是真的。然而，比尔·盖茨年轻、缺乏经验，也没有商业背景，但他似乎做得相当不错。

paragraphs.original: Steve Jobs got booted out of his own company by someone mature and experienced, with a business background, who then proceeded to ruin the company. So I think people who are mature and experienced, with a business background, may be overrated.
paragraphs.translated: 史蒂夫·乔布斯被一位成熟且有经验、具有商业背景的人从他自己的公司赶了出去，而这个人随后却把公司搞砸了。所以我认为，那些成熟、有经验且具有商业背景的人可能被高估了。

paragraphs.original: We used to call these guys "newscasters," because they had neat hair and spoke in deep, confident voices, and generally didn't know much more than they read on the teleprompter.We talked to a number of VCs, but eventually we ended up financing our startup entirely with angel money.
paragraphs.translated: 我们过去称这些人为“新闻播音员”，因为他们头发整洁，用深沉而自信的声音说话，而且通常他们知道的不会比从提词器上读到的多多少。我们与多位风险投资家进行了交谈，但最终我们完全通过天使投资为我们的初创公司融资。

paragraphs.original: The main reason was that we feared a brand-name VC firm would stick us with a newscaster as part of the deal. That might have been ok if he was content to limit himself to talking to the press, but what if he wanted to have a say in running the company?
paragraphs.translated: 主要原因是我们担心一家知名的风投公司会作为交易的一部分，给我们安排一位新闻主播。如果他满足于仅限于与媒体打交道，那可能还好；但如果他想参与公司的管理决策，那该怎么办？

paragraphs.original: That would have led to disaster, because our software was so complex. We were a company whose whole m.o. was to win through better technology. The strategic decisions were mostly decisions about technology, and we didn't need any help with those.This was also one reason we didn't go public.
paragraphs.translated: 那将会导致灾难，因为我们的软件非常复杂。我们是一家以通过更先进的技术取胜为经营方式的公司。战略决策大多是关于技术的，而这些方面我们并不需要任何帮助。这也是我们没有上市的一个原因。

paragraphs.original: Back in 1998 our CFO tried to talk me into it. In those days you could go public as a dogfood portal, so as a company with a real product and real revenues, we might have done well. But I feared it would have meant taking on a newscaster-- someone who, as they say, "can talk Wall Street's language."I'm happy to see Google is bucking that trend.
paragraphs.translated: 早在1998年，我们的首席财务官就尝试说服我。那时候，即使是一家宠物食品门户网站也能上市，所以作为一家拥有真正产品和实际收入的公司，我们可能会表现不错。但我担心这意味着要找一个能说“华尔街语言”的人——用他们的话说，就是“新闻播报员”。我很高兴看到谷歌正在打破这一趋势。

paragraphs.original: They didn't talk Wall Street's language when they did their IPO, and Wall Street didn't buy. And now Wall Street is collectively kicking itself. They'll pay attention next time. Wall Street learns new languages fast when money is involved.You have more leverage negotiating with VCs than you realize.
paragraphs.translated: 他们在进行IPO时没有使用华尔街的语言，华尔街没有买单。现在，华尔街集体后悔了。下次他们会留意的。涉及金钱时，华尔街会很快学会新语言。你与风险投资人的谈判中拥有的杠杆作用比你想象的要大。

paragraphs.original: The reason is other VCs. I know a number of VCs now, and when you talk to them you realize that it's a seller's market. Even now there is too much money chasing too few good deals.VCs form a pyramid.
paragraphs.translated: 原因是其他风险投资公司。我现在认识不少风险投资家，和他们交谈后你会意识到这是一个卖方市场。即使现在，也有太多的资金在追逐太少的好项目。风险投资公司形成了一个金字塔。

paragraphs.original: At the top are famous ones like Sequoia and Kleiner Perkins, but beneath those are a huge number you've never heard of. What they all have in common is that a dollar from them is worth one dollar. Most VCs will tell you that they don't just provide money, but connections and advice.
paragraphs.translated: 在最顶端的是像红杉和凯鹏华盈这样的知名机构，但在它们之下还有大量你从未听说过的风投。它们的共同点是，从它们那里得到的一美元价值就是一美元。大多数风投会告诉你，他们不仅提供资金，还提供关系网络和建议。

paragraphs.original: If you're talking to Vinod Khosla or John Doerr or Mike Moritz, this is true. But such advice and connections can come very expensive. And as you go down the food chain the VCs get rapidly dumber. A few steps down from the top you're basically talking to bankers who've picked up a few new vocabulary words from reading Wired.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是在和Vinod Khosla、John Doerr或Mike Moritz这样的人物交谈，情况确实如此。但这样的建议和关系网可能会非常昂贵。而当你往投资链的下游走时，风险投资家们的水平会迅速下降。从顶级往下几级，你基本上是在和那些从《连线》杂志上学到了几个新词汇的银行家们交谈。

paragraphs.original: (Does your product use XML?) So I'd advise you to be skeptical about claims of experience and connections. Basically, a VC is a source of money. I'd be inclined to go with whoever offered the most money the soonest with the least strings attached.You may wonder how much to tell VCs.
paragraphs.translated: （你的产品使用XML吗？）所以我建议你对那些关于经验和关系的说辞持怀疑态度。基本上，风险投资家就是资金的来源。我倾向于选择能最快提供最多资金且附加条件最少的投资者。你可能会疑惑该向风险投资家透露多少信息。

paragraphs.original: And you should, because some of them may one day be funding your competitors. I think the best plan is not to be overtly secretive, but not to tell them everything either. After all, as most VCs say, they're more interested in the people than the ideas.
paragraphs.translated: 你应该这样做，因为其中一些投资人未来可能会资助你的竞争对手。我认为最好的策略是不要过于保密，但也不要全盘托出。毕竟，正如大多数风险投资人所说，他们更看重人，而不是点子。

paragraphs.original: The main reason they want to talk about your idea is to judge you, not the idea. So as long as you seem like you know what you're doing, you can probably keep a few things back from them. [7]Talk to as many VCs as you can, even if you don't want their money, because a) they may be on the board of someone who will buy you, and b) if you seem impressive, they'll be discouraged from investing in your competitors.
paragraphs.translated: 他们想和你讨论你的想法主要是为了评判你，而不是你的想法。所以只要你显得对自己的事情了如指掌，你就可以对他们保留一些东西。尽可能多地与风险投资人交谈，即使你并不需要他们的资金，因为a) 他们可能在某个会收购你的公司的董事会中，b) 如果你看起来令人印象深刻，他们可能会被阻止去投资你的竞争对手。

paragraphs.original: The most efficient way to reach VCs, especially if you only want them to know about you and don't want their money, is at the conferences that are occasionally organized for startups to present to them.Not Spending ItWhen and if you get an infusion of real money from investors, what should you do with it?
paragraphs.translated: 接触风投最有效的方式，特别是当你只想让他们了解你而不想接受他们的资金时，是在偶尔为初创企业组织的路演活动中。当且如果从投资者那里获得资金注入时，你应该怎么做？

paragraphs.original: Not spend it, that's what. In nearly every startup that fails, the proximate cause is running out of money. Usually there is something deeper wrong. But even a proximate cause of death is worth trying hard to avoid.During the Bubble many startups tried to "get big fast." Ideally this meant getting a lot of customers fast.
paragraphs.translated: 不要花光它，这才是关键。几乎每个失败的初创公司，其直接原因都是资金耗尽。通常，背后还有更深层的问题。但即使是一个直接的致死原因，也值得努力去避免。在互联网泡沫时期，许多初创公司试图“快速做大”。理想情况下，这意味着迅速吸引大量客户。

paragraphs.original: But it was easy for the meaning to slide over into hiring a lot of people fast.Of the two versions, the one where you get a lot of customers fast is of course preferable. But even that may be overrated.
paragraphs.translated: 但这种含义很容易演变为快速招聘大量人员。在这两个版本中，当然是快速获得大量客户更可取。但即使是这一点也可能被高估了。

paragraphs.original: The idea is to get there first and get all the users, leaving none for competitors. But I think in most businesses the advantages of being first to market are not so overwhelmingly great. Google is again a case in point.
paragraphs.translated: 这个想法是抢先一步吸引所有用户，不让竞争对手有任何机会。但我认为在大多数业务中，成为市场先行者的优点并不是那么突出。谷歌就是一个很好的例子。

paragraphs.original: When they appeared it seemed as if search was a mature market, dominated by big players who'd spent millions to build their brands: Yahoo, Lycos, Excite, Infoseek, Altavista, Inktomi. Surely 1998 was a little late to arrive at the party.But as the founders of Google knew, brand is worth next to nothing in the search business.
paragraphs.translated: 当它们出现时，似乎搜索引擎已经是一个成熟的市场，由花费数百万建立品牌的大型企业主导：雅虎、Lycos、Excite、Infoseek、AltaVista、Inktomi。1998年进入这个领域显然有些晚了。但谷歌的创始人深知，在搜索引擎行业，品牌几乎一文不值。

paragraphs.original: You can come along at any point and make something better, and users will gradually seep over to you. As if to emphasize the point, Google never did any advertising. They're like dealers; they sell the stuff, but they know better than to use it themselves.The competitors Google buried would have done better to spend those millions improving their software.
paragraphs.translated: 你可以在任何时间加入并改进某件事情，用户会逐渐转向你。仿佛为了强调这一点，谷歌从未做过任何广告。他们就像经销商，他们出售产品，但自己却知道最好不要使用这些产品。被谷歌击败的竞争对手如果将那数百万资金用于改进软件，情况会好得多。

paragraphs.original: Future startups should learn from that mistake. Unless you're in a market where products are as undifferentiated as cigarettes or vodka or laundry detergent, spending a lot on brand advertising is a sign of breakage.
paragraphs.translated: 未来的初创企业应该从这个错误中吸取教训。除非你处于一个产品像香烟、伏特加或洗衣粉那样同质化的市场，否则在品牌广告上花费大量资金就表明存在问题。

paragraphs.original: And few if any Web businesses are so undifferentiated. The dating sites are running big ad campaigns right now, which is all the more evidence they're ripe for the picking. (Fee, fie, fo, fum, I smell a company run by marketing guys.)We were compelled by circumstances to grow slowly, and in retrospect it was a good thing.
paragraphs.translated: 几乎没有哪家网络公司的业务是如此缺乏差异化的。目前，交友网站正在大举投放广告，这更加证明它们已经成熟，可以被收购了。（哼，哈，呼，嘿，我闻到了市场营销人员的气息。）我们受制于环境，只能缓慢发展，而事后看来，这其实是一件好事。

paragraphs.original: The founders all learned to do every job in the company. As well as writing software, I had to do sales and customer support. At sales I was not very good. I was persistent, but I didn't have the smoothness of a good salesman.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人们都学会了公司里的每一份工作。除了编写软件，我还得做销售和客户服务。在销售方面，我做得并不出色。我很有毅力，但没有一个优秀销售员的那种圆滑。

paragraphs.original: My message to potential customers was: you'd be stupid not to sell online, and if you sell online you'd be stupid to use anyone else's software. Both statements were true, but that's not the way to convince people.I was great at customer support though.
paragraphs.translated: 我对潜在客户的信息是：如果你不上网销售，那你就太愚蠢了；而如果你上网销售，使用其他人的软件就更愚蠢了。这两句话都是事实，但用这种方式来说服人并不明智。不过，我在客户服务方面确实做得很好。

paragraphs.original: Imagine talking to a customer support person who not only knew everything about the product, but would apologize abjectly if there was a bug, and then fix it immediately, while you were on the phone with them.
paragraphs.translated: 想象一下，与一位不仅对产品了如指掌，而且在遇到漏洞时会真诚道歉，并在你通话过程中立即修复问题的客服人员交谈。

paragraphs.original: Customers loved us. And we loved them, because when you're growing slow by word of mouth, your first batch of users are the ones who were smart enough to find you by themselves. There is nothing more valuable, in the early stages of a startup, than smart users.
paragraphs.translated: 客户喜欢我们。我们也喜欢他们，因为当你通过口碑缓慢成长时，你的第一批用户是那些足够聪明能自己找到你的人。在创业初期，没有什么比聪明的用户更有价值的了。

paragraphs.original: If you listen to them, they'll tell you exactly how to make a winning product. And not only will they give you this advice for free, they'll pay you.We officially launched in early 1996. By the end of that year we had about 70 users.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你倾听他们，他们会告诉你如何制作一个成功的产品。他们不仅会免费给你这些建议，还会付钱给你。我们于1996年初正式推出。到那年年底，我们大约有70名用户。

paragraphs.original: Since this was the era of "get big fast," I worried about how small and obscure we were. But in fact we were doing exactly the right thing. Once you get big (in users or employees) it gets hard to change your product.
paragraphs.translated: 既然这是个“快速做大”的时代，我担心我们显得太小太不起眼。但实际上，我们正做着完全正确的事情。一旦你做大了（无论是用户数还是员工数），改变产品就会变得困难。

paragraphs.original: That year was effectively a laboratory for improving our software. By the end of it, we were so far ahead of our competitors that they never had a hope of catching up. And since all the hackers had spent many hours talking to users, we understood online commerce way better than anyone else.That's the key to success as a startup.
paragraphs.translated: 那一年实际上是一个改进我们软件的实验室。到了年底，我们已经远远领先于竞争对手，以至于他们再也没有希望追上我们。由于所有的黑客都花了大量时间与用户交流，我们对在线商务的理解远远超过了任何人。这就是作为初创公司成功的关键。

paragraphs.original: There is nothing more important than understanding your business. You might think that anyone in a business must, ex officio, understand it. Far from it. Google's secret weapon was simply that they understood search.
paragraphs.translated: 没有什么比理解你的业务更重要的了。你可能会认为，任何人只要在某项业务中，自然就应该理解这项业务。远非如此。谷歌的秘密武器就是他们对搜索的理解。

paragraphs.original: I was working for Yahoo when Google appeared, and Yahoo didn't understand search. I know because I once tried to convince the powers that be that we had to make search better, and I got in reply what was then the party line about it: that Yahoo was no longer a mere "search engine." Search was now only a small percentage of our page views, less than one month's growth, and now that we were established as a "media company," or "portal," or whatever we were, search could safely be allowed to wither and drop off, like an umbilical cord.Well, a small fraction of page views they may be, but they are an important fraction, because they are the page views that Web sessions start with.
paragraphs.translated: 我在雅虎工作时，谷歌出现了，而雅虎并不理解搜索的重要性。我知道这一点，因为我曾试图说服高层，我们必须改进搜索，而我得到的答复是当时公司的官方说辞：雅虎已经不再只是一个“搜索引擎”。搜索现在只占我们页面浏览量的一小部分，甚至不到一个月的增长量，既然我们已经确立为一家“媒体公司”或“门户网站”，搜索可以安全地被允许衰退和消失，就像脐带一样。好吧，这些页面浏览量虽然只占一小部分，但它们是非常重要的一部分，因为这些是网络会话开始时的页面浏览量。

paragraphs.original: I think Yahoo gets that now.Google understands a few other things most Web companies still don't. The most important is that you should put users before advertisers, even though the advertisers are paying and users aren't.
paragraphs.translated: 我认为雅虎现在明白了。谷歌理解了一些大多数网络公司仍然没有理解的事情。最重要的一点是，你应该把用户放在广告商之前，即使广告商在付费而用户没有。

paragraphs.original: One of my favorite bumper stickers reads "if the people lead, the leaders will follow." Paraphrased for the Web, this becomes "get all the users, and the advertisers will follow." More generally, design your product to please users first, and then think about how to make money from it.
paragraphs.translated: 我最喜欢的车贴标语之一是“如果人民领先，领导者就会跟随。”这句话改写成网络用语就是“吸引所有用户，广告商自然会跟进。”更普遍地说，设计产品时首先要取悦用户，然后再考虑如何从中盈利。

paragraphs.original: If you don't put users first, you leave a gap for competitors who do.To make something users love, you have to understand them. And the bigger you are, the harder that is. So I say "get big slow." The slower you burn through your funding, the more time you have to learn.The other reason to spend money slowly is to encourage a culture of cheapness.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你不把用户放在第一位，就会给那些这样做的竞争对手留下机会。要创造用户喜爱的产品，你必须了解他们。而且，你越大，这一点就越难做到。所以我建议“慢慢壮大”。你越慢花完资金，就越有时间去学习。缓慢花钱的另一个原因是培养一种节俭的文化。

paragraphs.original: That's something Yahoo did understand. David Filo's title was "Chief Yahoo," but he was proud that his unofficial title was "Cheap Yahoo." Soon after we arrived at Yahoo, we got an email from Filo, who had been crawling around our directory hierarchy, asking if it was really necessary to store so much of our data on expensive RAID drives.
paragraphs.translated: 这是雅虎明白的一点。戴维·费罗的头衔是“首席雅虎”，但他对自己的非正式头衔“省钱雅虎”感到自豪。我们刚到雅虎不久，就收到了费罗的电子邮件，他在我们的目录结构中翻找，询问我们是否真的有必要将这么多数据存储在昂贵的RAID磁盘上。

paragraphs.original: I was impressed by that. Yahoo's market cap then was already in the billions, and they were still worrying about wasting a few gigs of disk space.When you get a couple million dollars from a VC firm, you tend to feel rich.
paragraphs.translated: 我对此印象深刻。当时雅虎的市值已经达到了数十亿美元，但他们还在担心浪费几吉字节的磁盘空间。当你从风险投资公司拿到几百万美元时，往往会觉得自己很富有。

paragraphs.original: It's important to realize you're not. A rich company is one with large revenues. This money isn't revenue. It's money investors have given you in the hope you'll be able to generate revenues. So despite those millions in the bank, you're still poor.For most startups the model should be grad student, not law firm.
paragraphs.translated: 重要的是要意识到你并不是有钱的。一个富裕的公司是指有大量收入的公司。但这笔钱并不是收入，而是投资者寄希望于你能产生收入而给你的钱。所以，尽管银行里有数百万，你仍然是穷的。对于大多数初创公司来说，应该以研究生而不是律师事务所为模式。

paragraphs.original: Aim for cool and cheap, not expensive and impressive. For us the test of whether a startup understood this was whether they had Aeron chairs. The Aeron came out during the Bubble and was very popular with startups.
paragraphs.translated: 追求酷和便宜，而不是昂贵和令人印象深刻。对我们来说，测试一家初创公司是否理解这一点的标准是他们是否有Aeron椅子。Aeron椅子是在互联网泡沫时期推出的，非常受初创公司的欢迎。

paragraphs.original: Especially the type, all too common then, that was like a bunch of kids playing house with money supplied by VCs. We had office chairs so cheap that the arms all fell off. This was slightly embarrassing at the time, but in retrospect the grad-studenty atmosphere of our office was another of those things we did right without knowing it.Our offices were in a wooden triple-decker in Harvard Square.
paragraphs.translated: 特别是当时很普遍的那种类型，就像一群孩子在玩过家家，而资金则是由风险投资家提供的。我们用的办公椅非常便宜，以至于椅子的扶手都掉了。这在当时有点尴尬，但回想起来，我们办公室那种研究生的氛围是我们无意中做对的另一件事。我们的办公室位于哈佛广场的一栋三层木楼里。

paragraphs.original: It had been an apartment until about the 1970s, and there was still a claw-footed bathtub in the bathroom. It must once have been inhabited by someone fairly eccentric, because a lot of the chinks in the walls were stuffed with aluminum foil, as if to protect against cosmic rays.
paragraphs.translated: 直到20世纪70年代，这里还是一套公寓，浴室里还保留着一个爪足浴缸。住在这里的人一定相当古怪，因为墙上的许多缝隙都塞满了铝箔，仿佛是为了防止宇宙射线的侵袭。

paragraphs.original: When eminent visitors came to see us, we were a bit sheepish about the low production values. But in fact that place was the perfect space for a startup. We felt like our role was to be impudent underdogs instead of corporate stuffed shirts, and that is exactly the spirit you want.An apartment is also the right kind of place for developing software.
paragraphs.translated: 当有名望的访客来看我们时，我们对自己的低生产水平感到有些尴尬。但事实上，那个地方对初创公司来说是完美的空间。我们觉得自己应该扮演的是无畏的小人物，而不是公司的官僚，而这正是你想要的那种精神。公寓也是开发软件的理想场所。

paragraphs.original: Cube farms suck for that, as you've probably discovered if you've tried it. Ever notice how much easier it is to hack at home than at work? So why not make work more like home?When you're looking for space for a startup, don't feel that it has to look professional.
paragraphs.translated: 开放式办公区在这方面真的很糟糕，你可能已经发现了。是否注意到在家里编程比在办公室容易得多？那么为什么不把工作环境变得更像家一样呢？当你在为初创公司寻找办公空间时，不要觉得它一定要显得很专业。

paragraphs.original: Professional means doing good work, not elevators and glass walls. I'd advise most startups to avoid corporate space at first and just rent an apartment. You want to live at the office in a startup, so why not have a place designed to be lived in as your office?Besides being cheaper and better to work in, apartments tend to be in better locations than office buildings.
paragraphs.translated: 专业意味着做好工作，而不是电梯和玻璃墙。我建议大多数初创公司一开始避免租用企业办公空间，而是租一间公寓。在创业公司中，你希望住在办公室里，为什么不找一个设计用来居住的地方作为办公室呢？除了更便宜、更适合工作外，公寓通常比办公楼位置更好。

paragraphs.original: And for a startup location is very important. The key to productivity is for people to come back to work after dinner. Those hours after the phone stops ringing are by far the best for getting work done.
paragraphs.translated: 对于初创公司，地点非常重要。提高生产力的关键在于员工晚餐后能回到工作岗位。电话不再响起后的那些时间，是完成工作的最佳时段。

paragraphs.original: Great things happen when a group of employees go out to dinner together, talk over ideas, and then come back to their offices to implement them. So you want to be in a place where there are a lot of restaurants around, not some dreary office park that's a wasteland after 6:00 PM.
paragraphs.translated: 当一群员工一起出去吃饭，讨论想法，然后回到办公室实施这些想法时，伟大的事情就会发生。因此，你希望身处一个周围有很多餐厅的地方，而不是一个在下午6点后就变成荒地的沉闷办公园区。

paragraphs.original: Once a company shifts over into the model where everyone drives home to the suburbs for dinner, however late, you've lost something extraordinarily valuable. God help you if you actually start in that mode.If I were going to start a startup today, there are only three places I'd consider doing it: on the Red Line near Central, Harvard, or Davis Squares (Kendall is too sterile); in Palo Alto on University or California Aves; and in Berkeley immediately north or south of campus.
paragraphs.translated: 一旦公司转变为每个人都开车回家到郊区吃晚餐的模式，无论多晚，你就会失去一些极其宝贵的东西。如果你实际上从这种模式开始，那就更糟糕了。如果我今天要创办一家初创公司，我只会考虑三个地方：在中央、哈佛或戴维斯广场附近的红线上（肯德尔太冷清了）；在帕洛阿尔托的大学大道或加州大道；以及在伯克利校园的正北或正南。

paragraphs.original: These are the only places I know that have the right kind of vibe.The most important way to not spend money is by not hiring people. I may be an extremist, but I think hiring people is the worst thing a company can do.
paragraphs.translated: 这些是我所知道的唯一有那种氛围的地方。最节省开支的方式就是不雇人。我可能是个极端主义者，但我认为雇人是公司能做的最糟糕的事情。

paragraphs.original: To start with, people are a recurring expense, which is the worst kind. They also tend to cause you to grow out of your space, and perhaps even move to the sort of uncool office building that will make your software worse.
paragraphs.translated: 首先，人员是一笔经常性的开支，这是最糟糕的一种。他们还往往会促使你扩张超出现有空间，甚至可能不得不搬到那种不那么有吸引力的办公楼，这会使你的软件开发变得更糟。

paragraphs.original: But worst of all, they slow you down: instead of sticking your head in someone's office and checking out an idea with them, eight people have to have a meeting about it. So the fewer people you can hire, the better.During the Bubble a lot of startups had the opposite policy.
paragraphs.translated: 但最糟糕的是，他们拖慢了你的速度：原本你可以直接走进某人的办公室，和他们讨论一个想法，现在却要八个人开个会来讨论。所以，你能雇佣的人越少越好。在互联网泡沫时期，许多初创公司却采取了相反的政策。

paragraphs.original: They wanted to get "staffed up" as soon as possible, as if you couldn't get anything done unless there was someone with the corresponding job title. That's big company thinking. Don't hire people to fill the gaps in some a priori org chart.
paragraphs.translated: 他们希望尽快“充实人员”，好像没有相应职位的人就什么也做不了似的。这是大公司的思维方式。不要为了填补预先设定的组织结构图中的空缺而招聘人员。

paragraphs.original: The only reason to hire someone is to do something you'd like to do but can't.If hiring unnecessary people is expensive and slows you down, why do nearly all companies do it? I think the main reason is that people like the idea of having a lot of people working for them.
paragraphs.translated: 雇佣某人的唯一理由是去做你想要做但无法做的事情。如果雇佣不必要的人员既昂贵又会拖慢进度，那么为什么几乎所有的公司都会这样做呢？我认为主要原因是人们喜欢手下有很多人为他们工作的想法。

paragraphs.original: This weakness often extends right up to the CEO. If you ever end up running a company, you'll find the most common question people ask is how many employees you have. This is their way of weighing you.
paragraphs.translated: 这种弱点往往一直延伸到首席执行官。如果你将来经营一家公司，你会发现人们最常问的问题是你的公司有多少员工。这是他们衡量你的一种方式。

paragraphs.original: It's not just random people who ask this; even reporters do. And they're going to be a lot more impressed if the answer is a thousand than if it's ten.This is ridiculous, really. If two companies have the same revenues, it's the one with fewer employees that's more impressive.
paragraphs.translated: 不仅仅是普通人会问这个问题，记者也会问。而且，如果答案是一千，他们会被深深打动，而不是十个。这其实很荒谬。如果两家公司的收入相同，那么员工人数较少的那一家更令人印象深刻。

paragraphs.original: When people used to ask me how many people our startup had, and I answered "twenty," I could see them thinking that we didn't count for much. I used to want to add "but our main competitor, whose ass we regularly kick, has a hundred and forty, so can we have credit for the larger of the two numbers?"As with office space, the number of your employees is a choice between seeming impressive, and being impressive.
paragraphs.translated: 当人们过去问我我们创业公司有多少人时，我回答说“二十人”，我能看出他们在想我们没什么分量。我过去常常想补充说：“但是我们经常打败的主要竞争对手有140人，所以能不能把我们算作两者中人数较多的那一个？”和办公空间一样，你的员工人数是在显得有影响力和真正有影响力之间做出的选择。

paragraphs.original: Any of you who were nerds in high school know about this choice. Keep doing it when you start a company.Should You?But should you start a company? Are you the right sort of person to do it? If you are, is it worth it?More people are the right sort of person to start a startup than realize it.
paragraphs.translated: 任何在高中时是书呆子的人都知道这个选择。当你开始创业时，也要继续这样做。但是，你应该创业吗？你是不是适合创业的那类人？如果是，这样做值得吗？实际上，适合创业的人比意识到这一点的人要多。

paragraphs.original: That's the main reason I wrote this. There could be ten times more startups than there are, and that would probably be a good thing.I was, I now realize, exactly the right sort of person to start a startup.
paragraphs.translated: 这是我写这篇文章的主要原因。初创企业的数量可以是现在的十倍，这可能是一件好事。我现在意识到，我正是适合创办初创企业的人。

paragraphs.original: But the idea terrified me at first. I was forced into it because I was a Lisp hacker. The company I'd been consulting for seemed to be running into trouble, and there were not a lot of other companies using Lisp.
paragraphs.translated: 但这个想法最初让我感到害怕。我之所以被迫走上这条路，是因为我是一名Lisp程序员。我一直在提供咨询服务的那家公司似乎遇到了麻烦，而且当时使用Lisp的其他公司并不多。

paragraphs.original: Since I couldn't bear the thought of programming in another language (this was 1995, remember, when "another language" meant C++) the only option seemed to be to start a new company using Lisp.I realize this sounds far-fetched, but if you're a Lisp hacker you'll know what I mean.
paragraphs.translated: 由于我无法忍受用另一种语言（记住，这是1995年，那时“另一种语言”指的是C++）编程，所以唯一的选择似乎就是用Lisp启动一家新公司。我知道这听起来不太现实，但如果你是Lisp程序员，你就会明白我的意思。

paragraphs.original: And if the idea of starting a startup frightened me so much that I only did it out of necessity, there must be a lot of people who would be good at it but who are too intimidated to try.So who should start a startup?
paragraphs.translated: 如果开始一家创业公司让我如此害怕，以至于我只有在必要时才会去做，那么肯定有很多人虽然擅长这个，但由于害怕而不敢尝试。那么，谁应该创办创业公司呢？

paragraphs.original: Someone who is a good hacker, between about 23 and 38, and who wants to solve the money problem in one shot instead of getting paid gradually over a conventional working life.I can't say precisely what a good hacker is.
paragraphs.translated: 一个优秀的黑客，年龄在23到38岁之间，希望一次性解决金钱问题，而不是通过传统职业生涯逐渐获得报酬。我无法准确地说出什么样的人才算得上是一个优秀的黑客。

paragraphs.original: At a first rate university this might include the top half of computer science majors. Though of course you don't have to be a CS major to be a hacker; I was a philosophy major in college.It's hard to tell whether you're a good hacker, especially when you're young.
paragraphs.translated: 在一流的大学里，这可能包括计算机科学专业中排名前半的学生。当然，你不必是计算机科学专业的学生才能成为一名黑客；我在大学时主修的是哲学。很难判断你是否是一名优秀的黑客，尤其是在你年轻的时候。

paragraphs.original: Fortunately the process of starting startups tends to select them automatically. What drives people to start startups is (or should be) looking at existing technology and thinking, don't these guys realize they should be doing x, y, and z?
paragraphs.translated: 幸运的是，创业的过程往往会自动筛选出这样的人。促使人们创办初创企业的动力（或者说应该是）看到现有技术时会想，这些家伙难道没意识到他们应该做x、y和z吗？

paragraphs.original: And that's also a sign that one is a good hacker.I put the lower bound at 23 not because there's something that doesn't happen to your brain till then, but because you need to see what it's like in an existing business before you try running your own.
paragraphs.translated: 这同时也是成为优秀黑客的标志。我将下限设定为23岁，并不是因为大脑要到那时才会发生某些变化，而是因为在尝试自己创业之前，你需要先了解现有企业是什么样的。

paragraphs.original: The business doesn't have to be a startup. I spent a year working for a software company to pay off my college loans. It was the worst year of my adult life, but I learned, without realizing it at the time, a lot of valuable lessons about the software business.
paragraphs.translated: 这个企业不一定是初创公司。我曾在一家软件公司工作了一年，以还清我的大学贷款。那是我成年后最糟糕的一年，但我在那时不知不觉中学到了许多关于软件行业的宝贵经验。

paragraphs.original: In this case they were mostly negative lessons: don't have a lot of meetings; don't have chunks of code that multiple people own; don't have a sales guy running the company; don't make a high-end product; don't let your code get too big; don't leave finding bugs to QA people; don't go too long between releases; don't isolate developers from users; don't move from Cambridge to Route 128; and so on.
paragraphs.translated: 在这种情况下，大部分都是负面的经验教训：不要召开过多的会议；不要让多个人拥有同一段代码；不要让销售人员管理公司；不要制造高端产品；不要让代码变得过于庞大；不要把找虫子的任务留给质量保证人员；不要在发布之间间隔太久；不要让开发人员与用户隔离；不要从剑桥搬到128号公路沿线；等等。

paragraphs.original: [8] But negative lessons are just as valuable as positive ones. Perhaps even more valuable: it's hard to repeat a brilliant performance, but it's straightforward to avoid errors. [9]The other reason it's hard to start a company before 23 is that people won't take you seriously.
paragraphs.translated: [8] 但负面的教训和正面的经验一样宝贵。也许甚至更为宝贵：重复一次辉煌的表现很难，但避免错误却相对简单。[9] 另一个在23岁之前很难创业的原因是，人们不会认真对待你。

paragraphs.original: VCs won't trust you, and will try to reduce you to a mascot as a condition of funding. Customers will worry you're going to flake out and leave them stranded. Even you yourself, unless you're very unusual, will feel your age to some degree; you'll find it awkward to be the boss of someone much older than you, and if you're 21, hiring only people younger rather limits your options.Some people could probably start a company at 18 if they wanted to.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家不会信任你，会试图将你降格为吉祥物作为提供资金的条件。客户会担心你会敷衍了事，让他们陷入困境。即使是你自己，除非你是非同寻常的人，也会在某种程度上感受到年龄的影响；你会发现，当老板比你年长的人会感到尴尬，而如果你21岁，只招聘比你年轻的人，这将大大限制你的选择。有些人如果愿意，可能在18岁时就能创办公司。

paragraphs.original: Bill Gates was 19 when he and Paul Allen started Microsoft. (Paul Allen was 22, though, and that probably made a difference.) So if you're thinking, I don't care what he says, I'm going to start a company now, you may be the sort of person who could get away with it.The other cutoff, 38, has a lot more play in it.
paragraphs.translated: 比尔·盖茨在19岁时和保罗·艾伦创立了微软。（保罗·艾伦当时22岁，这可能有所不同。）所以，如果你在想，我不在乎他说什么，我现在就要创业，你可能是那种能够成功的人。另一个分界点，38岁，这个界限则更加灵活。

paragraphs.original: One reason I put it there is that I don't think many people have the physical stamina much past that age. I used to work till 2:00 or 3:00 AM every night, seven days a week. I don't know if I could do that now.Also, startups are a big risk financially.
paragraphs.translated: 我之所以这么认为，是因为我觉得大多数人过了那个年纪后体力就不如从前了。我以前每晚都会工作到凌晨2点或3点，一周七天无休。我不知道我现在还能不能做到。此外，创业在财务上风险也很大。

paragraphs.original: If you try something that blows up and leaves you broke at 26, big deal; a lot of 26 year olds are broke. By 38 you can't take so many risks-- especially if you have kids.My final test may be the most restrictive.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你26岁时尝试某件事失败了，甚至破产，那又怎样；很多26岁的人都破产了。但到了38岁，你就不能冒那么多险了——尤其是如果你有孩子的话。我的最终测试可能最为严格。

paragraphs.original: Do you actually want to start a startup? What it amounts to, economically, is compressing your working life into the smallest possible space. Instead of working at an ordinary rate for 40 years, you work like hell for four.
paragraphs.translated: 你真的想创办一家初创企业吗？从经济角度来看，这相当于将你的职业生涯压缩到最小的时间范围内。与其以普通速度工作40年，不如在4年内拼命工作。

paragraphs.original: And maybe end up with nothing-- though in that case it probably won't take four years.During this time you'll do little but work, because when you're not working, your competitors will be. My only leisure activities were running, which I needed to do to keep working anyway, and about fifteen minutes of reading a night.
paragraphs.translated: 也许最终一无所获——不过在这种情况下，大概也不会耗费四年的时间。在这段时间里，你几乎只会工作，因为当你不工作时，你的竞争对手们却在努力。我的唯一休闲活动就是跑步，而这其实也是为了保持工作状态所必需的，还有每天晚上大约十五分钟的阅读时间。

paragraphs.original: I had a girlfriend for a total of two months during that three year period. Every couple weeks I would take a few hours off to visit a used bookshop or go to a friend's house for dinner. I went to visit my family twice.
paragraphs.translated: 在那三年期间，我总共交往了一个女朋友，持续了两个月。每隔几周，我会请几个小时的假去逛旧书店或去朋友家吃晚饭。我回家看望家人两次。

paragraphs.original: Otherwise I just worked.Working was often fun, because the people I worked with were some of my best friends. Sometimes it was even technically interesting. But only about 10% of the time. The best I can say for the other 90% is that some of it is funnier in hindsight than it seemed then.
paragraphs.translated: 否则我就只是工作。工作常常很有趣，因为我与我共事的人中有一些是我最好的朋友。有时工作在技术上也很有趣。但这种情况只占大约10%的时间。对于其余90%的时间，我只能说其中一些事情事后回想起来比当时显得更有趣。

paragraphs.original: Like the time the power went off in Cambridge for about six hours, and we made the mistake of trying to start a gasoline powered generator inside our offices. I won't try that again.I don't think the amount of bullshit you have to deal with in a startup is more than you'd endure in an ordinary working life.
paragraphs.translated: 就像剑桥那次停电大约六个小时，我们犯了一个错误，试图在办公室内启动一台汽油发电机。我不会再试了。我认为在创业公司里你需要应对的麻烦并不会比在普通工作中遇到的更多。

paragraphs.original: It's probably less, in fact; it just seems like a lot because it's compressed into a short period. So mainly what a startup buys you is time. That's the way to think about it if you're trying to decide whether to start one.
paragraphs.translated: 实际上可能更少；只是因为这段时间被压缩得很短，所以感觉很多。因此，创业公司主要买给你的是时间。如果你在考虑是否要创业，这就是你应该考虑的方式。

paragraphs.original: If you're the sort of person who would like to solve the money problem once and for all instead of working for a salary for 40 years, then a startup makes sense.For a lot of people the conflict is between startups and graduate school.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是那种希望一次性解决金钱问题，而不是为了一份薪水工作40年的人，那么创业是有意义的。对很多人来说，选择的冲突在于创业和读研究生之间。

paragraphs.original: Grad students are just the age, and just the sort of people, to start software startups. You may worry that if you do you'll blow your chances of an academic career. But it's possible to be part of a startup and stay in grad school, especially at first.
paragraphs.translated: 研究生正好处在可以创办软件初创企业的年龄，也正合适这样做。你可能会担心这样做会破坏你在学术界发展的机会。但事实上，你可以在创业的同时继续攻读研究生，尤其是在创业初期。

paragraphs.original: Two of our three original hackers were in grad school the whole time, and both got their degrees. There are few sources of energy so powerful as a procrastinating grad student.If you do have to leave grad school, in the worst case it won't be for too long.
paragraphs.translated: 我们最初的三名黑客中有两名在整个期间都在读研究生，并且两人都获得了学位。没有什么能量来源比拖延的研究生更强大了。如果你不得不离开研究生院，最坏的情况也不会太久。

paragraphs.original: If a startup fails, it will probably fail quickly enough that you can return to academic life. And if it succeeds, you may find you no longer have such a burning desire to be an assistant professor.If you want to do it, do it.
paragraphs.translated: 如果一家初创公司失败了，它可能会迅速失败，使你能够回到学术生涯。如果它成功了，你可能会发现自己不再那么强烈地渴望成为一名助理教授。如果你想做就去做吧。

paragraphs.original: Starting a startup is not the great mystery it seems from outside. It's not something you have to know about "business" to do. Build something users love, and spend less than you make. How hard is that?Notes[1] Google's revenues are about two billion a year, but half comes from ads on other sites.[2] One advantage startups have over established companies is that there are no discrimination laws about starting businesses.
paragraphs.translated: 创办一家初创公司并不像外界看起来那么神秘。这并不是你必须了解“商业”才能去做的事情。创建一些用户喜欢的东西，并且支出少于收入。这有多难呢？注释[1] 谷歌的年收入约为20亿美元，但其中一半来自其他网站上的广告收入。[2] 初创公司相对于成熟公司的一个优势是，关于创办企业的过程中没有歧视法律的限制。

paragraphs.original: For example, I would be reluctant to start a startup with a woman who had small children, or was likely to have them soon. But you're not allowed to ask prospective employees if they plan to have kids soon.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，我不愿意与有年幼孩子的女性或即将要孩子的女性共同创办一家初创公司。但你不能问潜在员工他们是否打算近期要孩子。

paragraphs.original: Believe it or not, under current US law, you're not even allowed to discriminate on the basis of intelligence. Whereas when you're starting a company, you can discriminate on any basis you want about who you start it with.[3] Learning to hack is a lot cheaper than business school, because you can do it mostly on your own.
paragraphs.translated: 不管你信不信，根据现行的美国法律，你甚至不允许以智力为由进行歧视。然而，当你创办公司时，你可以根据自己的意愿，以任何理由选择与谁一起创业。[3] 学习黑客技术比上商学院便宜得多，因为你可以主要靠自己来完成。

paragraphs.original: For the price of a Linux box, a copy of K&R, and a few hours of advice from your neighbor's fifteen year old son, you'll be well on your way.[4] Corollary: Avoid starting a startup to sell things to the biggest company of all, the government.
paragraphs.translated: 只需支付一台Linux服务器的费用、一本《K&R》的价钱，再加上你邻居家十五岁儿子的几小时建议，你就走上正轨了。[4] 推论：避免创办一家初创公司去向最大的客户——政府销售产品。

paragraphs.original: Yes, there are lots of opportunities to sell them technology. But let someone else start those startups.[5] A friend who started a company in Germany told me they do care about the paperwork there, and that there's more of it.
paragraphs.translated: 是的，有很多机会可以向他们出售技术。但让别人去创办这些初创企业吧。[5] 一位在德国创办公司的朋友告诉我，那里确实很重视文书工作，而且量也更多。

paragraphs.original: Which helps explain why there are not more startups in Germany.[6] At the seed stage our valuation was in principle $100,000, because Julian got 10% of the company. But this is a very misleading number, because the money was the least important of the things Julian gave us.[7] The same goes for companies that seem to want to acquire you.
paragraphs.translated: 这有助于解释为什么德国没有更多的创业公司。[6] 在种子阶段，我们的估值原则上是10万美元，因为朱利安获得了公司10%的股份。但这是一个非常具有误导性的数字，因为朱利安给我们的钱是最不重要的东西。[7] 对于那些似乎想要收购你的公司也是如此。

paragraphs.original: There will be a few that are only pretending to in order to pick your brains. But you can never tell for sure which these are, so the best approach is to seem entirely open, but to fail to mention a few critical technical secrets.[8] I was as bad an employee as this place was a company.
paragraphs.translated: 有些人只是假装这样做以便从你那里获取信息。但你永远无法确定这些人究竟是谁，所以最好的办法是表现得非常坦诚，但不要提及几个关键的技术秘密。我曾是这里最糟糕的员工，就像这里曾是最糟糕的公司一样。
